elements.content: Breaking the cycle of silver pyrazolates: instead of the common loops (e.g., the Ag3N6 ring), we report an infinite array in which the equispaced Ag­(I) ions form a zigzag chain, with the associated anthracene bis­(pyrazolate) linkers cofacially aligned one to another. In addition to the strong Ag­(I)–N bonds and the distinct argentophilic interactions, the Ag­(I) ions also form interlayer, metal−π contacts with the anthracene cores. The resultant two-dimensional network exhibits significant electronic interaction between the Ag­(I) centers and the large aromatic linker molecule, as revealed by the red shift of photoemission spectra and the significant reduction of the electronic band edge as determined by diffuse reflectance spectroscopy. The solid sample is stable in air and water.
elements.clean_text: Breaking the cycle of silver pyrazolates: instead of the common loops (e.g., the Ag3N6 ring), we report an infinite array in which the equispaced Ag(I) ions form a zigzag chain, with the associated anthracene bis(pyrazolate) linkers cofacially aligned one to another. In addition to the strong Ag(I)-N bonds and the distinct argentophilic interactions, the Ag(I) ions also form interlayer, metal-π contacts with the anthracene cores. The resultant two-dimensional network exhibits significant electronic interaction between the Ag(I) centers and the large aromatic linker molecule, as revealed by the red shift of photoemission spectra and the significant reduction of the electronic band edge as determined by diffuse reflectance spectroscopy. The solid sample is stable in air and water.

elements.content:
Silver lining: a string of argentophilic Ag­(I) ions and straddling large aromatic pyrazolate linkers form a 2D network to impact significantly the photoluminescence and optical absorption properties.

There is ongoing interest in constructing electronically integrated coordination networks featuring significant electronic interaction between the organic π-electron systems and metal centers. To overcome the van der Waals barrier and promote charge transport across the organic molecules, molecular packing that optimizes the intermolecular orbital overlap (i.e., the transfer integral) has proven a key factor in the high charge carrier mobilities observed of many organic semiconductors. Of late, the use of metal–ligand interactions (e.g., coordination bonds) to promote electronic communications throughout the solid state has also witnessed significant progress. Among these, metal–thiolate network systems are noted because of the soft, highly polarizable nature of the sulfur donors and their effective electronic interaction across the metal center and the organic π-system, e.g., to result in even metallic conductivity. Nitrogen-based donor groups also offer considerable potential in this regard because of their diverse chemical functionalities (e.g., as amines and N-heterocycles).
elements.clean_text:
Silver lining: a string of argentophilic Ag(I) ions and straddling large aromatic pyrazolate linkers form a 2D network to impact significantly the photoluminescence and optical absorption properties.

There is ongoing interest in constructing electronically integrated coordination networks featuring significant electronic interaction between the organic π-electron systems and metal centers. To overcome the van der Waals barrier and promote charge transport across the organic molecules, molecular packing that optimizes the intermolecular orbital overlap (i.e., the transfer integral) has proven a key factor in the high charge carrier mobilities observed of many organic semiconductors. Of late, the use of metal-ligand interactions (e.g., coordination bonds) to promote electronic communications throughout the solid state has also witnessed significant progress. Among these, metal-thiolate network systems are noted because of the soft, highly polarizable nature of the sulfur donors and their effective electronic interaction across the metal center and the organic π-system, e.g., to result in even metallic conductivity. Nitrogen-based donor groups also offer considerable potential in this regard because of their diverse chemical functionalities (e.g., as amines and N-heterocycles).

elements.content: Against this backdrop, we have designed the organic linker [9,10-di­(1H-pyrazol-4-yl)­anthracene; H2DPA] featuring the large π-system of anthracene coupled with two 4-pyrazolyl groups, which, in the deprotonated form, offers four N donors for strong and extensive bonding with metal ions. A more specific design arises from an earlier observation that, in coordination hybrids containing one-dimensional (1D) inorganic moieties, large aromatic planes (e.g., with three or more fused rings) tend to form into cofacial (e.g., NOT edge-to-face) stacks that parallel the inorganic chains. For illustration, a 1D CuCN chain with stacks of an anthracene-based ligand is shown in Figure S1. The distinct coexistence of coordination chains and aromatic stacks directs our attention to Ag­(I) pyrazolate complexes, which, curiously, have been extensively found to adopt discrete, cyclic Ag­(I)–N coordination motifs, while chain-like Ag­(I)–N motifs in Ag­(I) pyrazolates are much rarer. In particular, we wonder if infinite, chain-like Ag­(I)–N domains can be induced by large aromatic ligands, in order to increase the dimensionality of the coordination domain and improve the connectivity between the organic and metallic moieties.
elements.clean_text: Against this backdrop, we have designed the organic linker [9,10-di(1H-pyrazol-4-yl)anthracene; H2DPA] featuring the large π-system of anthracene coupled with two 4-pyrazolyl groups, which, in the deprotonated form, offers four N donors for strong and extensive bonding with metal ions. A more specific design arises from an earlier observation that, in coordination hybrids containing one-dimensional (1D) inorganic moieties, large aromatic planes (e.g., with three or more fused rings) tend to form into cofacial (e.g., NOT edge-to-face) stacks that parallel the inorganic chains. For illustration, a 1D CuCN chain with stacks of an anthracene-based ligand is shown in Figure S1. The distinct coexistence of coordination chains and aromatic stacks directs our attention to Ag(I) pyrazolate complexes, which, curiously, have been extensively found to adopt discrete, cyclic Ag(I)-N coordination motifs, while chain-like Ag(I)-N motifs in Ag(I) pyrazolates are much rarer. In particular, we wonder if infinite, chain-like Ag(I)-N domains can be induced by large aromatic ligands, in order to increase the dimensionality of the coordination domain and improve the connectivity between the organic and metallic moieties.

elements.content: In this context, the new Ag­(I) pyrazolate network compound Ag2(DPA), with its menagerie of interconnecting bonding and argentophilic, metal−π and face-to-face aromatic stacking interactions, presents points of interest. The organic linker [9,10-di­(1H-pyrazol-4-yl)­anthracene; H2DPA] here is a large, polarizable π-electron system containing an anthracene equipped with two 4-pyrazolyl groups. In the deprotonated form, the DPA2– dianion offers four N donors for strong and extensive bonding with metal ions. Most notably, the single crystal structure of the Ag2(DPA) network features an infinite bonding motif among the Ag­(I) centers and the pyrazolate units, with distinct equispaced Ag atoms strung together through argentophilic interactions. The extended, 1D Ag­(I)–N domains in Ag2(DPA) stand out from the discrete coordination cycles commonly found in other Ag­(I) pyrazolate complexes, offering more extensive interactions between the organic and metallic moieties in the resultant layer-like coordination net.
elements.clean_text: In this context, the new Ag(I) pyrazolate network compound Ag2(DPA), with its menagerie of interconnecting bonding and argentophilic, metal-π and face-to-face aromatic stacking interactions, presents points of interest. The organic linker [9,10-di(1H-pyrazol-4-yl)anthracene; H2DPA] here is a large, polarizable π-electron system containing an anthracene equipped with two 4-pyrazolyl groups. In the deprotonated form, the DPA2- dianion offers four N donors for strong and extensive bonding with metal ions. Most notably, the single crystal structure of the Ag2(DPA) network features an infinite bonding motif among the Ag(I) centers and the pyrazolate units, with distinct equispaced Ag atoms strung together through argentophilic interactions. The extended, 1D Ag(I)-N domains in Ag2(DPA) stand out from the discrete coordination cycles commonly found in other Ag(I) pyrazolate complexes, offering more extensive interactions between the organic and metallic moieties in the resultant layer-like coordination net.

elements.content: The molecule H2DPA was prepared by a Suzuki coupling reaction between commercially available 9,10-dibromoanthracene and pyrazole-4-boronic acid pinacol ester (). The single crystal sample of the Ag2(DPA) network was obtained using a reported protocol. Specifically, an ethanol solution of H2DPA (0.0155 g, 0.05 mmol in 5.0 mL) was carefully layered onto an aqueous ammonia solution (26%) of Ag2O (0.0116 g, 0.05 mmol in 5.0 mL). After 2 weeks, yellowish block crystals were collected and washed with ethanol (yield, 13.6 mg; 52% based on H2DPA). Chemical analysis of the solid product C20H12N4Ag2 yielded the following: calcd [C (45.84%), H (2.31%), N (10.69%)]; found [C (45.25%), H (2.44%), N (10.55%)]. The solid sample of Ag2(DPA) is air stable and insoluble in water and common organic solvents, while an X-ray powder diffraction study indicates a pure crystalline phase consistent with the single-crystal structure ().
elements.clean_text: The molecule H2DPA was prepared by a Suzuki coupling reaction between commercially available 9,10-dibromoanthracene and pyrazole-4-boronic acid pinacol ester (). The single crystal sample of the Ag2(DPA) network was obtained using a reported protocol. Specifically, an ethanol solution of H2DPA (0.0155 g, 0.05 mmol in 5.0 mL) was carefully layered onto an aqueous ammonia solution (26%) of Ag2O (0.0116 g, 0.05 mmol in 5.0 mL). After 2 weeks, yellowish block crystals were collected and washed with ethanol (yield, 13.6 mg; 52% based on H2DPA). Chemical analysis of the solid product C20H12N4Ag2 yielded the following: calcd [C (45.84%), H (2.31%), N (10.69%)]; found [C (45.25%), H (2.44%), N (10.55%)]. The solid sample of Ag2(DPA) is air stable and insoluble in water and common organic solvents, while an X-ray powder diffraction study indicates a pure crystalline phase consistent with the single-crystal structure ().

PXRD patterns (Cu Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å): ): (a) calculated from the single-crystal structure (with no preferred orientation); (b) calculated from the single-crystal structure, with the parameter of preferred orientation R0 for 011 set at 2 using the Materials Studio software (March-Dollase); (c) measured from an as-made bulk sample of Ag2(DPA).
elements.clean_text: 1  PXRD patterns (Cu Kα, λ = 1.5418 Å): ): (a) calculated from the single-crystal structure (with no preferred orientation); (b) calculated from the single-crystal structure, with the parameter of preferred orientation R0 for 011 set at 2 using the Materials Studio software (March-Dollase); (c) measured from an as-made bulk sample of Ag2(DPA).

elements.content: The X-ray single-crystal structure of Ag2(DPA) () adopts the monoclinic space group P21/n (No. 14). The asymmetric portion of the unit cell contains half of a DPA molecule and one Ag­(I) ion. The two contiguous N atoms of each pyrazolate unit form strong bonds to the Ag­(I) centers at distances: Ag1–N1, 2.099(4) Å, and Ag1–N2, 2.086(4) Å, respectively. Each Ag­(I) is coordinated to two nitrogen donors in a nearly linear fashion, N–Ag–N, 164.6°. The Ag ions constitute a zigzag chain, with a bend of 131.7°, and an even spacing of Ag···Ag at the short contact of 3.141 Å (cf. van der Waals distance between Ag atoms: 3.4 Å), which points to a distinct argentophilic interaction. The space between the neighboring Ag atoms are straddled by the pyrazolate units to form a 1D Ag­(I)–N chain along which the DPA linkers are organized in a herringbone-like array (i.e., along the b axis), featuring intermolecular C···C distances of 3.480 Å among the cofacially stacked anthracene units. The strong stacking interaction among the large-π DPA linker molecules, in parallel to the chain-like coordination domain of the Ag­(I) ions and the pyrazolate donors, suggests some correlation between the two, e.g., the stacking of the anthracene units likely helps to force the Ag­(I)–N to adopt the linear motif of Ag2(DPA). The linear, polymeric motif here contrasts the discrete, cyclic Ag­(I)–pyrazolate patterns that are commonly known; the latter are exemplified by the trimeric (Ag3N6) and tetrametic (Ag4N8) rings in .
elements.clean_text: The X-ray single-crystal structure of Ag2(DPA) () adopts the monoclinic space group P21/n (No. 14). The asymmetric portion of the unit cell contains half of a DPA molecule and one Ag(I) ion. The two contiguous N atoms of each pyrazolate unit form strong bonds to the Ag(I) centers at distances: Ag1-N1, 2.099(4) Å, and Ag1-N2, 2.086(4) Å, respectively. Each Ag(I) is coordinated to two nitrogen donors in a nearly linear fashion, N-Ag-N, 164.6°. The Ag ions constitute a zigzag chain, with a bend of 131.7°, and an even spacing of Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag at the short contact of 3.141 Å (cf. van der Waals distance between Ag atoms: 3.4 Å), which points to a distinct argentophilic interaction. The space between the neighboring Ag atoms are straddled by the pyrazolate units to form a 1D Ag(I)-N chain along which the DPA linkers are organized in a herringbone-like array (i.e., along the b axis), featuring intermolecular C⋅⋅⋅C distances of 3.480 Å among the cofacially stacked anthracene units. The strong stacking interaction among the large-π DPA linker molecules, in parallel to the chain-like coordination domain of the Ag(I) ions and the pyrazolate donors, suggests some correlation between the two, e.g., the stacking of the anthracene units likely helps to force the Ag(I)-N to adopt the linear motif of Ag2(DPA). The linear, polymeric motif here contrasts the discrete, cyclic Ag(I)-pyrazolate patterns that are commonly known; the latter are exemplified by the trimeric (Ag3N6) and tetrametic (Ag4N8) rings in .

elements.content: Two-dimensional coordination grid from the single crystal structure of Ag2DPA (viewed along the c axis), featuring infinite, zigzag strings of equispaced Ag atoms bonded with straddling pyrazolate units. Ag atoms, green; N atoms, mauve; C atoms, gray. Hydrogen omitted for clarity. Black dashed lines: C···C contacts of 3.480 Å. Green dashed lines: Ag···Ag contacts of 3.141 Å. Ag1–N1, 2.099 Å; Ag1–N2, 2.086 Å.

Ag atoms, green; N atoms, mauve; C atoms, gray. Hydrogen omitted for clarity. Black dashed lines: C⋅⋅⋅C contacts of 3.480 Å. Green dashed lines: Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag contacts of 3.141 Å. Ag1-N1, 2.099 Å; Ag1-N2, 2.086 Å.

elements.content: Trimeric (a) and tetrameric (b) coordination motifs for illustrating the discrete, cyclic Ag­(I) pyrazolate complexes commonly found in the literature.
elements.clean_text: 3  Trimeric (a) and tetrameric (b) coordination motifs for illustrating the discrete, cyclic Ag(I) pyrazolate complexes commonly found in the literature.

elements.content: Around each Ag­(I), the two nitrogen donors, together with two neighboring Ag­(I) centers, form the lopsided geometry of a distorted square pyramid (), with open space opposite the base occupied by two carbon atoms from the neighboring layer, so as to form distinct cation−π interactions, i.e., Ag1–C9, 2.958; Ag–C10, 2.937 Å (). Altogether, the Ag2(DPA) network features a rare case of conjoining the four forces of face-to-face interaction, the argentophilic interaction, and the Ag­(I)−π and Ag­(I)–pyrazolate bonding to promote intermolecular interactions both within and across the layers.
elements.clean_text: Around each Ag(I), the two nitrogen donors, together with two neighboring Ag(I) centers, form the lopsided geometry of a distorted square pyramid (), with open space opposite the base occupied by two carbon atoms from the neighboring layer, so as to form distinct cation-π interactions, i.e., Ag1-C9, 2.958; Ag-C10, 2.937 Å (). Altogether, the Ag2(DPA) network features a rare case of conjoining the four forces of face-to-face interaction, the argentophilic interaction, and the Ag(I)-π and Ag(I)-pyrazolate bonding to promote intermolecular interactions both within and across the layers.

elements.content: Perspective view (along b axis) of the single crystal structure of Ag2DPA, highlighting the lopsided geometry of a distorted square pyramid of Ag­(I) centers. Ag atoms, green; N atoms, purple; C atoms, white. The dashed lines indicate the distances between the Ag and C atoms from neighboring layers: Ag1–C9, 2.958; Ag–C10, 2.937 Å. Hydrogen omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 4  Perspective view (along b axis) of the single crystal structure of Ag2DPA, highlighting the lopsided geometry of a distorted square pyramid of Ag(I) centers. Ag atoms, green; N atoms, purple; C atoms, white. The dashed lines indicate the distances between the Ag and C atoms from neighboring layers: Ag1-C9, 2.958; Ag-C10, 2.937 Å. Hydrogen omitted for clarity.

elements.content: In addition, the molecular packing motif of the DPA units in the Ag2(DPA) network is also markedly different from that of the molecular crystal of H2DPA·MeOH (MeOH being the methanol molecule being included from the crystallization process). Unlike the face-to-face stacking (e.g., C···C distances of 3.480 Å) observed in Ag2(DPA), the crystal structure of H2DPA·MeOH (Figure S4) exhibits no parallel, cofacial aromatic stacking; instead, an angle of 36.2° was found between the neighboring anthracene moieties (C···C contacts: 3.605, 3.675 Å and above). Overall, the H2DPA molecules are organized in a layered fashion, with the hydrophobic hydrocarbon portions alternating with the more polar/hydrophilic pyrazole N domain. Within the hydrophilic domain are also intercalated methanol guest molecules, giving a composition of H2DPA·MeOH. Overall, the face-to-face packing induced in the coordination net of Ag2(DPA) is reminiscent of a previously reported case.
elements.clean_text: In addition, the molecular packing motif of the DPA units in the Ag2(DPA) network is also markedly different from that of the molecular crystal of H2DPA⋅MeOH (MeOH being the methanol molecule being included from the crystallization process). Unlike the face-to-face stacking (e.g., C⋅⋅⋅C distances of 3.480 Å) observed in Ag2(DPA), the crystal structure of H2DPA⋅MeOH (Figure S4) exhibits no parallel, cofacial aromatic stacking; instead, an angle of 36.2° was found between the neighboring anthracene moieties (C⋅⋅⋅C contacts: 3.605, 3.675 Å and above). Overall, the H2DPA molecules are organized in a layered fashion, with the hydrophobic hydrocarbon portions alternating with the more polar/hydrophilic pyrazole N domain. Within the hydrophilic domain are also intercalated methanol guest molecules, giving a composition of H2DPA⋅MeOH. Overall, the face-to-face packing induced in the coordination net of Ag2(DPA) is reminiscent of a previously reported case.

elements.content: Diffuse reflectance measurements of the solid sample of Ag2(DPA) indicated an electronic bandgap of 2.4 eV (Figure S5), whereas the molecular solids of H2DPA (obtained by rotary evaporation of a CHCl3 solution; crystallinity relatively poor, see Figure S6) and H2DPA·MeOH (crystals obtained by slow evaporation from a methanol solution) both exhibit larger band gaps around 2.7 eV. Further theoretical studies may unveil the origin of the smaller band gap of the coordination network Ag2(DPA), so as to quantify the contributions from the Ag–pyrazolate bonding as well as the distinct short contacts such as argentophilic and cation−π interactions. The photoluminescence spectra are also measured on H2DPA, H2DPA·MeOH, and the network sample Ag2(DPA) (; see also Figure S7 for emission spectra at various concentrations of MeOH). The methanol solution of H2DPA featured a strong emission with the maximum (λem,max) at 438 nm, while the λem,max of the powder sample of H2DPA was red-shifted to 460 nm with slight shouldering at about 500 nm. The shouldering feature, which can be ascribed to excimer emission, becomes a broad, strong peak (λem,max = 500 nm) in the more crystalline sample of H2DPA·MeOH; and it becomes even stronger (i.e., relative to the monomer emission around 460 nm) in the network crystal of Ag2(DPA) (λem,max = 506 nm). The dominant excimer emission in Ag2(DPA) is in line with the close, face-to-face alignment of the anthracene π-planes; prior to this study, smaller angles between anthracene moieties (i.e., closer to being parallel) have also been observed to favor excimer emission in a similar anthracene-based system. In addition to the excimer and monomer emissions, the Ag2(DPA) crystal also emits around 420 nm, which arises likely from a ligand-centered emission from the DPA moieties in the network, and from a metal-centered transition (Ag+, ds/dp) modified by argentophilic interactions.
elements.clean_text: Diffuse reflectance measurements of the solid sample of Ag2(DPA) indicated an electronic bandgap of 2.4 eV (Figure S5), whereas the molecular solids of H2DPA (obtained by rotary evaporation of a CHCl3 solution; crystallinity relatively poor, see Figure S6) and H2DPA⋅MeOH (crystals obtained by slow evaporation from a methanol solution) both exhibit larger band gaps around 2.7 eV. Further theoretical studies may unveil the origin of the smaller band gap of the coordination network Ag2(DPA), so as to quantify the contributions from the Ag-pyrazolate bonding as well as the distinct short contacts such as argentophilic and cation-π interactions. The photoluminescence spectra are also measured on H2DPA, H2DPA⋅MeOH, and the network sample Ag2(DPA) (; see also Figure S7 for emission spectra at various concentrations of MeOH). The methanol solution of H2DPA featured a strong emission with the maximum (λem,max) at 438 nm, while the λem,max of the powder sample of H2DPA was red-shifted to 460 nm with slight shouldering at about 500 nm. The shouldering feature, which can be ascribed to excimer emission, becomes a broad, strong peak (λem,max = 500 nm) in the more crystalline sample of H2DPA⋅MeOH; and it becomes even stronger (i.e., relative to the monomer emission around 460 nm) in the network crystal of Ag2(DPA) (λem,max = 506 nm). The dominant excimer emission in Ag2(DPA) is in line with the close, face-to-face alignment of the anthracene π-planes; prior to this study, smaller angles between anthracene moieties (i.e., closer to being parallel) have also been observed to favor excimer emission in a similar anthracene-based system. In addition to the excimer and monomer emissions, the Ag2(DPA) crystal also emits around 420 nm, which arises likely from a ligand-centered emission from the DPA moieties in the network, and from a metal-centered transition (Ag+, ds/dp) modified by argentophilic interactions.

elements.content: Room-temperature solid-state emission spectra of H2DPA in MeOH solution (green graph, cc = 0.4 mmol/L), H2DPA powder (from rotary evaporation of a chloroform solution; black graph), H2DPA·MeOH solid (from slow crystallization from a methanol solution; blue graph), and Ag2(DPA) solid (magenta graph) under 360 nm excitation.
elements.clean_text: 5  Room-temperature solid-state emission spectra of H2DPA in MeOH solution (green graph, cc = 0.4 mmol/L), H2DPA powder (from rotary evaporation of a chloroform solution; black graph), H2DPA⋅MeOH solid (from slow crystallization from a methanol solution; blue graph), and Ag2(DPA) solid (magenta graph) under 360 nm excitation.

elements.content: In conclusion, by drawing on the crystal engineering observation on coexisting large aromatics and 1D coordination chains, we have designed a large aromatic linker H2DPA and consequently accessed an infinite Ag­(I) pyrazolate chain, a bonding motif that breaks from the isolated coordination cycles of many other Ag­(I) pyrazolates. The coordination motif in the solid state is, however, also governed by other bonding and packing factors, and further studies are still needed to test the applicability of the observed correlation of cofacial aromatics and linear motifs. The novel coordination motif of Ag2(DPA), together with its remarkable collection of intermolecular interactions (e.g., the argentophilic interactions and Ag­(I)−π contacts), nevertheless highlight the importance of large aromatic linkers for solid state materials research.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, by drawing on the crystal engineering observation on coexisting large aromatics and 1D coordination chains, we have designed a large aromatic linker H2DPA and consequently accessed an infinite Ag(I) pyrazolate chain, a bonding motif that breaks from the isolated coordination cycles of many other Ag(I) pyrazolates. The coordination motif in the solid state is, however, also governed by other bonding and packing factors, and further studies are still needed to test the applicability of the observed correlation of cofacial aromatics and linear motifs. The novel coordination motif of Ag2(DPA), together with its remarkable collection of intermolecular interactions (e.g., the argentophilic interactions and Ag(I)-π contacts), nevertheless highlight the importance of large aromatic linkers for solid state materials research.

cln_elements.content: The molecule H2DPA was prepared by a Suzuki coupling reaction between commercially available 9,10-dibromoanthracene and pyrazole-4-boronic acid pinacol ester (). The single crystal sample of the Ag2(DPA) network was obtained using a reported protocol. Specifically, an ethanol solution of H2DPA (0.0155 g, 0.05 mmol in 5.0 mL) was carefully layered onto an aqueous ammonia solution (26%) of Ag2O (0.0116 g, 0.05 mmol in 5.0 mL). After 2 weeks, yellowish block crystals were collected and washed with ethanol (yield, 13.6 mg; 52% based on H2DPA). Chemical analysis of the solid product C20H12N4Ag2 yielded the following: calcd [C (45.84%), H (2.31%), N (10.69%)]; found [C (45.25%), H (2.44%), N (10.55%)]. The solid sample of Ag2(DPA) is air stable and insoluble in water and common organic solvents, while an X-ray powder diffraction study indicates a pure crystalline phase consistent with the single-crystal structure ().

Chemical analysis of the solid product C20H12N4Ag2 yielded the following: calcd [C (45.84%), H (2.31%), N (10.69%)]; found [C (45.25%), H (2.44%), N (10.55%)]. cln_elements.content: Two-dimensional coordination grid from the single crystal structure of Ag2DPA (viewed along the c axis), featuring infinite, zigzag strings of equispaced Ag atoms bonded with straddling pyrazolate units. Ag atoms, green; N atoms, mauve; C atoms, gray. Hydrogen omitted for clarity. Black dashed lines: C···C contacts of 3.480 Å. Green dashed lines: Ag···Ag contacts of 3.141 Å. Ag1–N1, 2.099 Å; Ag1–N2, 2.086 Å.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Two-dimensional coordination grid from the single crystal structure of Ag2DPA (viewed along the c axis), featuring infinite, zigzag strings of equispaced Ag atoms bonded with straddling pyrazolate units. Ag atoms, green; N atoms, mauve; C atoms, gray. Hydrogen omitted for clarity. Black dashed lines: C⋅⋅⋅C contacts of 3.480 Å. Green dashed lines: Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag contacts of 3.141 Å. Ag1-N1, 2.099 Å; Ag1-N2, 2.086 Å.

cln_elements.content: Trimeric (a) and tetrameric (b) coordination motifs for illustrating the discrete, cyclic Ag­(I) pyrazolate complexes commonly found in the literature.

cln_elements.content: Perspective view (along b axis) of the single crystal structure of Ag2DPA, highlighting the lopsided geometry of a distorted square pyramid of Ag­(I) centers. Ag atoms, green; N atoms, purple; C atoms, white. The dashed lines indicate the distances between the Ag and C atoms from neighboring layers: Ag1–C9, 2.958; Ag–C10, 2.937 Å. Hydrogen omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: Room-temperature solid-state emission spectra of H2DPA in MeOH solution (green graph, cc = 0.4 mmol/L), H2DPA powder (from rotary evaporation of a chloroform solution; black graph), H2DPA·MeOH solid (from slow crystallization from a methanol solution; blue graph), and Ag2(DPA) solid (magenta graph) under 360 nm excitation.

metadata.title:
Beadwork and Network: Strings of Silver Ions Stitch
Large‑π Pyrazolate Patches into a Two-dimensional Sheet
